content: flying dutchman socks by caoua coffee materials solid colored fingering weight sock yarn 230yds/210m 280yds/260m in dark color d 135yds/125m 165yds/150m in light color l note make sure there really is a harsh light/dark contrast between the colors needles us1/2 25mm and us 1 5/2 5mm or size to obtain gauge stitch marker tapestry needle size women s us 7-8 9-10 gauge 34 sts/48 row= 4 inches on smaller needles abbreviations d = work with dark color k = knit stitch k2tog = knit 2 together l = work with light color m1 = make 1 stitch insert left needle from front to back under strand of yarn which runs between last stitch on left needle and first stitch on right needle knit this stitch through back loop p = purl stitch p2tog = purl 2 together rs = right side / public side / outside of sock sl = slip_stitch as if to purl while leaving yarn end behind hanging on the inside of the sock sl yb = slip_stitch as if to purl with yarn in back back = the side away from you sl yf = slip_stitch as if to purl with yarn in front front = the side closest to you ssk = slip 1 knit wise slip 1 purl wise knit both stitches together through the back loops st s = stitch es turn = turn your work so that the other side is facing you and you can start to work back on the stitches you have just worked this means - if you have been knitting before the turn you will be purling back these stitches after the turn while inside/purl-side of sock is facing you - if you have been purling before the turn you will be knitting back these stitches after the turn while outside/knit-side of sock is facing you tw = twist the 2 strands of yarn round each other to avoid holes ws = wrong side / private side / inside of sock ©caoua coffee 2013 pattern is for non-commercial personal use only all rights reserved flying dutchman v 1 2 page 1/6 flying dutchman socks - by caoua coffee pattern before you start these socks feature an intarsia motif but unlike standard flat intarsia patterns they are knitted in the round and form a tube on the go as standard socks do to make this happen you will work back and forth on your stitches i e there are frequent turns where you purl back with the inside of the sock facing you than turn again to continue knitting with outside facing but don t fear the whole pattern is written out stitch by stitch since i couldn t find a way to convincingly chart the process the chart is added as a visual aid only - to help you understand what you are doing and what it is supposed to look like as with any regular intarsia pattern when you switch from one color to the other
